questions.text: A 57 yrs old female complains of diminution of vision,pain in eyes and frontal headache. On examination her RAPD and color vision is also found impaired. On funduscopy the below image is seen. Which of the following will you not consider?
questions.solution:
The patient seems to be suffering from Retrobulbar neuritis.

Vitamin A when taken in excessive amounts can lead to development of pseudo tumor cerebri. This may lead to developing papilloedema of both eyes.

Optic neuritis:

  • Three types: 1. Retrobulbar 2. Papillitis Neuroretinitis

Retrobulbar neuritis

  • Optic nerve head not involved
  • Most common type in adults
  • Seen in multiple sclerosis

Papillits

  • Hyperemic and edematous ONH
  • Most common in children
  • Infective causation

Neuroretinits

  • Least common type
  • Papillitis with macular star
  • Seen in demyelinating disorders

Neuromyelitis optica

  • Devic disease
  • Autoimmune disease with antibodies against Aquaporin 4 in cell membrane of astrocytes
  • Any age
  • Bilateral optic neuritis

Option A :Multiple sclerosis

  • Demyelinating disorder
  • Women> men
  • 30s to 40s age group
  • Ophthalmic features: optic neuritis, INO and nystagmus. Hemianopia, ocular motor nerve palsies
  • Inv: lumbar puncture shows oligoclonal bands, MRI shows lesions in brain and changes in optic nerve. VEP shows conduction delay and decreased amplitude

Treatment:

  1. consider for IV MPS, 1g for 3 days followed by oral predni 1mg per kg per day.
  2. Interferon beta for MS early cases
  3. Progressive MS: ocrelizumab.

questions.text: All of the following is true about the condition shown in the image, except:
questions.solution:
The above image insinuates "Papilloedema". Can be due to Pseudotumor Cerebri (benign Intracranial hypertension-IIH) or space occupying lesion leading to raised Intracranial HTN

  • Optic disc edema(usually bilateral) due to increased intracranial pressure is called "papilloedema"
  • hydrostatic, non-inflammatory phenomenon
  • edema occurs per-laminate cribrosa
  • Foster-Kennedy syndrome: unilateral papilloedema, with or without optic atrophy on the other side, suggests a tumor of opposite olfactory groove or orbital surface of the frontal lobe or of pituitary body.
  • Aetiology: A) Intracranial tumor causing raised intracranial tension b) pseudotumor cerebri- raised intracranial tension in abscence of tumor.
  • Symptoms: unilateral or bilateral "blackouts", relative scotoma to green and red. DOV and loss of vision with chronic papilloedema
  • D/D: ischemic optic neuropathy, optic disc drusen, pseudoneuritis,papillitis

questions.text: A 58 yrs old patient presented to us with below findings. What advice will you give to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from "Right sixth nerve palsy".

Paralysis of Lateral Rectus(6th CN):

  • Homonymous diplopia looking towards the paralyzed side
  • limitation of Abduction of affected side with face turn towards affected side
  • Esotropia in primary position(MR overaction)
  • commonly idiopathic and microvascular causes(60%)
  • investigate for Microvascular lesions, trauma, giant cell arteritis and symptoms of ear disease
  • bilateral acute 6th nerve palsy is rare, rule out raised Intracranial tension.
  • Investigation: Neuroimaging. Look for GCA. Look for predisposing factors- hypertension, hyperlipidemia and diabetes mellitus

Treatment:

  • 90% recover spontaneously
  • observation with monocular occlusion or prismatic correction of diplopia
  • young child needs alternate patching to prevent amblyopia
  • botulinum toxin- on the same side Medial rectus. Prevents contracture,not curative
  • surgery- only if no improvement post 6-12 months of treatment.

questions.text: A diabetic patient has presented with the following findings. Everything is true regarding the condition, except:
questions.solution:
Third nerve palsy:

the third nerve can be affected in:

1. Nuclear complex:

2. fasciculus:

  • the syndromes are known as- benedikt, nothnagel, Weber and claude(benedikt+nothnagel) and Raymond

3. basilar:

  • third nerve travels alone in the base of skull, so Isolated third nerve palsy is common.
  • Causes: aneurysm(post communicating artery) and head trauma

4. intracavernous:

usually in this area 3rd N palsy is not isolated.

associated with 4th and 6th and V1(1st part of trigmenial) palsy

  • Third N. lies above the fourth N and divides into superior and inferior branch anteriorly
  • causes of palsy in this area: Diabetes, pituitary apoplexy, carotid o-cavernous fistula, tolosa-hunt syndrome etc

5. intraorbital

  • Innervates levator and SR(superior division) and MR, IR and IO muscles(inferior)
  • IO branch has preganglionic fibres- sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles.
  • Inferior division lesions: limited adduction and depression with dilated pupil
  • causes: commonly traumatic or vascular

6. pupillomotor fibres

  • Location: superomedial part of 3rd N, between brain stem and cavernous sinus
  • blood supply: pial vessels (unlike main stem-supplied by vasa vasorum)
  • "pupil sparing lesion" is medical cause: eg. hypertension and diabetes. Microangiopathy of vasa vasorum
  • "surgical" cause": aneurysm, trauma and uncal herniation- compression of pial vessels and affects superficial pupillary fibres

SIGNS:

  • Ptosis: d/t levator muscle weakness
  • down and out eye: d/t unopposed action of lateral rectus and superior oblique
  • Dilated pupil with defective accommodation in Parasympathetic involvement

Aberrant regeneration:

  • Pseudo- Von Graefe phenomenon: due to re-innervation of incorrect extraocular muscles
  • Elevation of upper lid on attempting adduction or depression
  • Doesn't occur if cause is vascular cause as endoneural nerve sheaths are preserved.

Treatment:

  • Observation in microvascular cases
  • Temporary fresnel prism
  • Botulinum toxin in lateral rectus to avoid contracture in long term
  • surgical- only after 6-12 months of adequate treatment has passed

questions.text: Patient presents to you with the below findings. Patient is unable to look towards right side with left eye and has nystagmus in right eye on looking towards right. The findings are as conferred in the image. What is true about the condition the patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from INO.

Abnormality of Horizontal gaze

  • Horizontal gaze palsy
  • internuclear ophthalmoplegia(INO)
  • bilateral INO
  • One and half syndrome

Horizontal gaze palsy:

  • lesion in PPRF
  • ipsilateral side lesion
  • inability to look in direction of lesion

INO:

  • Lesion in MLF
  • causes: demyelination got syndromes, stroke and tumours.

The image for bilateral INO: limitation of adduction on both sides with intact convergence.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: One and half syndrome:

  • PPRF+MLF Lesion: on same side
  • ipsilateral gaze palsy and INO.
  • remaining movement: abduction of contralateral eye.(but has abducting nystagmus)

questions.text: Which of the following drug causes a finding as shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
The image shows optic atrophy, as seen by the pale discs

  • Ethambutol produces Optic neuritis- complaints: decreased visual acuity, color vision and central scotoma. It can lead to secondary optic atrophy with chronic use.
  • Neuritis is reversible, when drug is discontinued.
  • Dose- 15 mg/kg/day upper limit of safety.
  • Optic atrophy is also reported in use of Isoniazid and streptomycin

questions.text: All of the following is true about optic nerve, except:
questions.solution:
• Microscopically "Peripheral nerves" possesses Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and macrophages.
  • Microscopically "Optic nerve" consists of Oligodendrocytes, astrocytes and microglia.

Important points about Optic nerve:

  • Consists of 2 million axons and are second order neurons
  • has four parts: Intra-ocular(1 mm), intra-orbital(25-30 mm), intra-canalicular(5-9 mm) and intra-cranial(10-16 mm)
  • Diseases of optic nerve and macula mimic each other, because 80% fibres originate from macular region
  • Optic nerve cannot regenerate.
  • Optic nerve is covered with Pia, arachnoid and dura mater post laminate cribrosa
